title: Controlling waves in magnets with superconductors for the first time
description: Quantum physicists at Delft University of Technology have shown that it's possible to control and manipulate spin waves on a chip using superconductors for the first time. These tiny waves in magnets may offer an alternative to electronics in the future. The study, published in Science, primarily gives physicists new insight into the interaction between magnets and superconductors.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers report effect of hypoxia on periosteal stem cells
description: A new study has shown that the interaction of miR-584-5p and RUNX2 could mediate PSC osteogenic differentiation induced by hypoxia. The work is published in the World Journal of Stem Cells.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Effects of integrated rice-crayfish farming on soil biodiversity and functions
description: Global food security is currently challenged by global changes, population expansion, and resource constrains. Integrated farming has been proposed as a sustainable approach to boost food production by taking advantage of the synergies between contrasting edible animal and crop species.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: UK study finds some species of seabirds are showing signs of developing immunity to avian influenza
description: As part of a major research consortium announced last June, the UK's top scientists have discovered that some seabirds are demonstrating immunity to avian influenza.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Increasing vegetable crops will not ease hunger if supply chains don't keep pace
description: We might think that if you want to feed more people in areas with food insecurity, you can just grow more food. But it isn't that simple.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Endangered whales live in area earmarked for gas exploration
description: Endangered whales and dolphins live year-round in an area of the Mediterranean earmarked for oil and gas exploration, new research shows.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Something to chew on: Researchers look for connections in how animals eat and digest food
description: UMass Lowell's Nicolai Konow wants to bridge the gap between research on food processing and nutrient absorption. "There is a divide between biomechanists, who study chewing and food transport, and physiologists, who examine what actually happens to food in the gastrointestinal tract," said the assistant professor of biological sciences.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Examining how Mei-yu precipitation responds to climate change
description: Mei-yu (i.e., plume rain) is a distinct weather phenomenon in East Asia during summer, which is generally characterized by persistent rainy and cloudy weather in the middle-lower Yangtze River valley (hereinafter referred to as YRV) region from mid-June to early July. Under global warming, anomalous Mei-yu has caused severe meteorological disasters during recent years.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Making high-quality crystals that resonate strongly with infrared light
description: Combining electronics with infrared light can enable small, fast, and sensitive devices for sensing, imaging, and signaling at the molecular level. However, in the infrared spectrum, materials must meet strict quality requirements for their crystals in order to meet the requirements for these functions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Recent advances in Raman spectroelectrochemistry on single-crystal surfaces
description: Benefiting from a principally contaminant-free and well-defined surface, single-crystal electrodes proffer new insights into interfacial processes and are important in electrochemistry. The surface atom density can be utilized to quantitatively explain the reaction process as a function of adsorbate coverage and catalytic reaction rate.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Gene discovery may help growers battle grape downy mildew
description: Researchers at Cornell have discovered a new grape downy mildew resistance gene—giving the wine and grape industry a powerful new tool to combat this devastating disease.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Designing marine protected areas in the fight against climate change
description: An international team has developed the first comprehensive framework for designing networks of marine protected areas that can help vulnerable species survive as climate change drives habitat loss.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New measuring tool tracks food security over time
description: Researchers from the Charles H. Dyson School of Applied Economics and Management have developed a new method for measuring food insecurity, which for millions of people in the U.S. is more than just an abstract concept.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Female computer engineering students obtain better grades and prefer more people-oriented specializations: Report
description: In academic year 2021/2022, men formed a clear majority of students studying for a Bachelor's Degree in Computer Engineering in Spain. According to the report "Igualdad en cifras" ("Equality in Figures") published by the Spanish Ministry of Education and Vocational Training, only 14.1% of all students taking that program were women.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research sheds light on early galaxy formation
description: Researchers have developed a new computer simulation of the early universe that closely aligns with observations made by the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New article argues that human right to the environment must be recognized in order to restore our planet
description: A new article by environmental lawyer Prof. Nicholas A. Robinson sees the recognition of the Human Right to the Environment (HRE) as a first step in a long process of restoring a healthy environment for people and the planet.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists find two ways that hurricanes rapidly intensify
description: Hurricanes that rapidly intensify for mysterious reasons pose a particularly frightening threat to those in harm's way. Forecasters have struggled for many years to understand why a seemingly commonplace tropical depression or tropical storm sometimes blows up into a major hurricane, packing catastrophic winds and driving a potentially deadly surge of water toward shore.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists identify gene that triggers dramatically increased root growth
description: Oak Ridge National Laboratory scientists identified a gene "hotspot" in the poplar tree that triggers dramatically increased root growth. The discovery supports the development of better bioenergy crops and other plants that can thrive in difficult conditions while storing more carbon belowground.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New quantum computing architecture achieves electron charge qubit with 0.1 millisecond coherence time
description: Coherence stands as a pillar of effective communication, whether it is in writing, speaking or information processing. This principle extends to quantum bits, or qubits, the building blocks of quantum computing. A quantum computer could one day tackle previously insurmountable challenges in climate prediction, material design, drug discovery and more.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Could technology help reduce pretrial incarceration?
description: Right now, thousands of people across the U.S. are in prison awaiting trial for a misdemeanor charge. A growing body of research indicates that if someone had sent each of them a text message at just the right time, with just the right message, a significant number may not have wound up there.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Insights for plant breeding: Arming wheat plants against climate stress with microorganisms
description: Agriculture in Europe is increasingly affected by extreme weather conditions that lead to crop losses. In 2018, the damage in Germany alone amounted to around 770 million euros. Making wheat plants more resilient to these stresses could make a significant contribution to safeguarding global food production.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: What's inside the Carina pillars? Massive protostars and newly forming planets
description: Star-forming nebulae are busy places. Unfortunately, clouds of gas and dust usually hide the action. To cut through the dust in one such region, a team of astronomers used the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA). They peered inside the Pillars of the Carina Nebula and studied molecular outflows (or jets) emanating from objects in this famous star-birth nursery.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How to prepare for a trip to space
description: Aleksandra Stankovic is an aerospace psychologist and spaceflight biomedical researcher who studies how to optimize human performance and behavioral health in extreme operational environments. In this article, she describes how a person gets ready to travel to space.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A decision-support tool gives second life to food waste
description: European scientists, companies and clusters developed a decision-support tool that identifies what residues from food production can be recycled and how. The software supports a decision-making process that is not only based on technical criteria, but also on economic and sustainable aspects.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Developing brand relationships through social media communication: A cross-cultural comparison
description: The effect of different cultural characteristics can affect the relationships consumers using social media have with different brands, according to research published in the International Journal of Electronic Marketing and Retailing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Image: Readying a little rover
description: An engineer prepares a small rover for testing in a thermal vacuum chamber on Oct. 24, 2023, at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Digital terrain models zero in on Martian surface
description: Picture soaring over a rugged canyon on another world, strapped into an imaginary hang glider. Or getting a bird's eye view of craters that stretch on for miles and following along the same paths as the robotic rovers that have explored the surface of Mars. All of this is possible—virtually—thanks to specialists at the University of Arizona's Lunar and Planetary Laboratory.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The intricate mechanisms of epigenetic silencing
description: Epigenetic silencing, which involves the suppression of gene activity, is a fascinating and increasingly influential branch of biological sciences. It allows cells to remember and maintain specific gene expression patterns throughout development and respond to environmental cues such as winter cold in the case of vernalization in plants.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Why are so many migrant families still separated? Chaos in the data
description: Five years since the retraction of the Trump-era zero-tolerance policy on illegal border crossings, which resulted in the separation of more than 5,000 children from their families at the U.S.-Mexico border between 2017 and 2021, a task force is still attempting to reunify and account for separated families.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Discovery of three novel Minorisa species, the smallest predatory marine picoplankton
description: Minorisa, a group of unicellular eukaryotes (protists), is renowned as one of the smallest predators in the world. These microorganisms are widely distributed in oceans, with a particular abundance in coastal regions, where they are believed to play a crucial role in marine ecosystems.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The 'spinaron': New quantum effect challenges the long-held Kondo effect
description: For the first time, experimental physicists from the Würzburg-Dresden Cluster of Excellence ct.qmat have demonstrated a new quantum effect aptly named the "spinaron." In a meticulously controlled environment and using an advanced set of instruments, they managed to prove the unusual state a cobalt atom assumes on a copper surface.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Fruit, nectar, bugs and blood: How bat teeth and jaws evolved for a diverse dinnertime
description: They don't know it, but Darwin's finches changed the world. These closely related species—native to the Galapagos Islands—each sport a uniquely shaped beak that matches their preferred diet. Studying these birds helped Charles Darwin develop the theory of evolution by natural selection.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Agronomists find green way to mitigate the effects of soil salinity
description: Most crops are sensitive to soil salinity. Excess salts cause salt stress—plants lack water, photosynthesis is suppressed, respiration worsens, chlorophyll breaks down, and potassium ions leak. Water-soluble toxic salts stimulate the synthesis of reactive oxygen species that destroys cells. Due to global climate change, there is more saline land.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Low self-regulation in smartphone use is connected to online shopping addiction
description: A recent article from a joint study by the Department of Social Sciences and Philosophy at the University of Jyväskylä and the Department of Education at the University of Helsinki is among the first peer-reviewed scientific publications exploring the co-effects of problems with self-regulation and smartphone use on shopping addiction. The research is published in the International Journal of Consumer Studies.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Farmed wolffish could be on your plate in the future
description: In the future, farmed wolffish could start appearing on fish counters. However, a new thesis from the University of Gothenburg shows that this fish, with its delicate, firm flesh, needs somewhat different farming conditions compared to salmon.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Acquiring green firms can be healthy for a firm's bottom line, says new research
description: There is some good news for companies looking to add to their green credentials. According to a new Concordia-led study, when firms acquire businesses specializing in green technologies or green brands, the buyer usually sees positive stock market reactions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Media failed to highlight the negative impact of single-use facemasks on the environment, says review
description: A multidisciplinary team from Bangor has shown how media messaging could have determined people's mask-wearing choices during the pandemic. This was based on a qualitative and quantitative review of British and Irish press coverage mentioning masks and face coverings between March 2020 and December 2021.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Investigating the difference between consent and coercion in 'voluntary' resettlement in Tibet
description: The difference between voluntary and involuntary participation may seem clear, but a study from the Tibet Autonomous Region shows the distinction between the two can, in fact, be murky.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A framework for screening pharmaceuticals and personal care products in landfill leachates
description: The prevalence of pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs) in the environment has generated increasing concern due to the potential threats they pose to the ecosystem and human health. Landfill leachate is an important source of PPCPs in water; however, it has rarely been involved in source apportionment due to the lack of indicator-PPCPs (i-PPCPs) in landfill leachates.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study enhances validation of MERRA-2 aerosol optical thickness dataset in China
description: A new study published in Atmosphere on Oct. 23 has made advances in the validation of MERRA-2 Aerosol Optical Thickness dataset in China. The study was conducted by scientists from the Aerospace Information Research Institute (AIR) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Singles become pairs: New insights into the light scattering of atoms
description: Researchers headed by Jürgen Volz and Arno Rauschenbeutel from the Department of Physics at the Humboldt University of Berlin, partners of the DAALI project, have gained new insights into the scattering of light by a fluorescent atom, which could also be useful for quantum communication. The research team has now published their results in the journal Nature Photonics.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Mammalian cells may consume bacteria-killing viruses to promote cellular health
description: Bacteriophages, also called phages, are viruses that infect and kill bacteria, their natural hosts. But from a macromolecular viewpoint, phages can be viewed as nutritionally enriched packets of nucleotides wrapped in an amino acid shell.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research finds stress and strain changes metal electronic structure
description: New research from the University of Birmingham shows that the electronic structure of metals can strongly affect their mechanical properties.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers find first proof of menopause in wild chimpanzees
description: A team of researchers studying the Ngogo community of wild chimpanzees in western Uganda's Kibale National Park for two decades has published a report in Science showing that females in this population can experience menopause and post-reproductive survival.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Superatomic semiconductor sets a speed record for ballistic flow
description: Semiconductors—most notably, silicon—underpin the computers, cellphones, and other electronic devices that power our daily lives, including the device on which you are reading this article.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Astronomers want JWST to study the Milky Way core for hundreds of hours
description: To understand the universe, we need to understand the extreme processes that shape it and drive its evolution. Things like supermassive black holes (SMBHs,) supernovae, massive reservoirs of dense gas, and crowds of stars both on and off the main sequence. Fortunately there's a place where these objects dwell in close proximity to one another: the Milky Way's galactic center (GC.)
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Civilizations are probably spreading quickly through the universe, researchers claim
description: The Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI) has always been plagued by uncertainty. With only one habitable planet (Earth) and one technologically advanced civilization (humanity) as examples, scientists are still confined to theorizing where other intelligent life forms could be (and what they might be up to).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: After DART smashed into Dimorphous, what happened to the larger asteroid Didymos?
description: NASA's DART mission (Double Asteroid Redirection Test) slammed into asteroid Dimorphos in September 2022, changing its orbital period. Ground and space-based telescopes turned to watch the event unfold, not only to study what happened to the asteroid, but also to help inform planetary defense efforts that might one day be needed to mitigate potential collisions with our planet.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Io has 266 active volcanic hotspots linked by a global magma ocean, finds study
description: Jupiter's Io stands apart from the solar system's other moons, with its numerous volcanoes and its surface dominated by lava flows. Io's surface volcanism was confirmed in 1979 when the Voyager spacecraft imaged it, but its volcanic nature isn't duplicated anywhere else in our system. Tidal heating is behind the moon's eruptive nature, driven by Jupiter's powerful gravity, and by resonance with other moons. But is there a magma ocean inside Io?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Designing natural language processing tools for teachers
description: According to a 2022 Gallup poll, U.S. teachers in grades K-12 are the most burnt-out workers in any profession. Could natural language processing tools (NLP) support them?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: All mines eventually close—how can mining towns like Mount Isa best manage the ups and downs?
description: The announcement by Glencore last week that its Mount Isa copper mines will close in 2025 is significant for the town.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: AI could free up time to solve the world's problems, suggests hydrology expert
description: A Charles Darwin University (CDU) water expert who uses ChatGPT to analyze hydrological data in a fraction of time says artificial intelligence (AI) could allow researchers to dedicate more time to the world's most pressing problems.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Workplace tensions: How and when bystanders can make a difference
description: In today's climate of global political tensions and polarization, workplaces are filled with conflicting viewpoints. When employees hold political identities and perspectives that do not align with their co-workers, they perceive greater incivility from them, which can result in greater stress and burnout.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA improves GIANT optical navigation technology for future missions
description: Goddard's GIANT optical navigation software helped guide the OSIRIS-REx mission to the Asteroid Bennu. Today its developers continue to add functionality and streamline useability for future missions.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA's first two-way end-to-end laser communications system
description: NASA is demonstrating laser communications on multiple missions—showcasing the benefits infrared light can have for science and exploration missions transmitting terabytes of important data.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Dark matter scientists receive first transmissions from deep underground
description: Scientists have received the first transmissions from a muon detector placed 1 km underground in the Stawell Underground Physics Laboratory.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Exploring long-lasting effects of pre-phase landslides on future landslide occurrences
description: A research team from the Aerospace Information Research Institute (AIR) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences has explored the long-lasting effects of pre-phase landslides on future landslide occurrences and evaluated the susceptibility of regions prone to seismic events.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Wokewashing undermines the credibility of CEO sociopolitical communications: Study
description: CEOs are increasingly participating in sociopolitical debates. However, their efforts can be ineffective, or even backfire, if consumers view the statements as unauthentic, according to a new international study.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Wild animals that survive limb loss are astonishing. And a sign of the havoc humans are wreaking on nature
description: It might seem astounding that a wild animal could survive a limb amputation and still thrive in the wild but videos from social media and research show this may be more common than people realize. Many wild animals not only survive the health risks of amputation, but go on to learn how to adapt to their new bodies, whether by themselves or with the help of others in their family.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Investigating the effects of surface treatment on the antibacterial activity of wood
description: Research indicates that several pathogenic bacteria can remain contagious on a range of surfaces from hours to days and weeks. While wood as a surface material is known for its antibacterial properties, dry contamination via hands has so far been poorly understood, as most prior research has involved adding bacteria in liquid droplets to materials.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Uranus aurora discovery offers clues to habitable icy worlds
description: The presence of an infrared aurora on the cold, outer planet of Uranus has been confirmed for the first time by University of Leicester astronomers.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Bed bugs are a global problem, yet we still know little about how they spread
description: Bed bugs have recently exploded into the limelight amid widespread reports of a major outbreak in Paris. The more people share photos of bed bug bites on social media, the more concerned we feel. That's understandable, but the really worrying thing is the missing information—there is still no publicly available data about the infestations in Paris.

title: Is your dog better or worse off on a cereal-free diet?
description: If there's one issue that has gripped the dog-loving community for the past few years, it's that of cereals in dog food, and in particular in the ingredients that make up kibbles.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Astronomers capture formation of a powerful cosmic jet
description: Using a network of radio telescopes on Earth and in space, astronomers have captured the most detailed view ever of a jet of plasma from a supermassive black hole. The jet travels at nearly the speed of light and shows complex, twisted patterns near its source. These patterns challenge the standard theory that has been used for 40 years to explain how these jets form and change over time.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Calls grow in Europe for wealth tax to finance the green transition

title: Toxic diets: Canadian orcas face high risks of pollution-related health effects

title: Drug detection dogs often get it wrong, and it's a policing practice that needs to stop
description: Drug detection dogs are a street-level policing strategy that has now been used in Australia for more than 25 years.

title: New mapping tools will find subsurface water ice on Mars

title: Do or dye: Synthetic colors in wastewater pose a threat to food chains worldwide

title: Venus had Earth-like plate tectonics billions of years ago, study suggests
description: Venus, a scorching wasteland of a planet according to scientists, may have once had tectonic plate movements similar to those believed to have occurred on early Earth, a new study found. The finding sets up tantalizing scenarios regarding the possibility of early life on Venus, its evolutionary past and the history of the solar system.

title: Measuring mechanical stresses and strains in graphene-based supercapacitor electrodes

This finding can be used to design new materials for flexible electronics or other devices that must be both strong and store energy efficiently.

title: Tiny networks intertwine to mimic design of bird colors

title: Can AI nip tree disease in the bud?
description: Global trade, tourism and other forms of human movement are accelerating the spread of tree and plant pathogens between continents. Dutch elm disease, first seen in Europe in 1910, was detected in Canada just four decades later. Since then, it has destroyed billions of elm trees in in North America and Europe.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Mystery of volcanic tsunami solved after 373 years
description: The explosion of the underwater volcano Kolumbo in the Aegean Sea in 1650 triggered a destructive tsunami that was described by historical eye witnesses. A group of researchers led by Dr. Jens Karstens from the GEOMAR Helmholtz Centre for Ocean Research Kiel has now surveyed Kolumbo's underwater crater with modern imaging technology and reconstructed the historical events.

title: Recycling used wood can make a big contribution to net zero, but needs much better coordination

title: Research shows bone density is maintained by proteins that are also involved in hair color

title: Black families are being squeezed out of homeownership by corporate investors
description: In the years since the Great Recession, when housing prices dramatically fell, Wall Street investors have been buying large numbers of single-family homes to use as rentals. As of 2022, big investment firms owned nearly 600,000 such properties nationwide.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The sun's activity cycle is reaching its peak early—knowing why could help us unlock the secrets of our star
description: Our sun is a steady and everlasting companion. Reliable like a clock, its apparent passage across the sky allows us to measure time. The sun and its path is also the source of Earth's seasons. But in many respects, our sun is far from calm and unchanging.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Men say they are spending more time on household chores, and would like to do more—survey of 17 countries
description: Women perform between three and seven times more caregiving tasks than men in the global south. These include household domestic work and largely focus on caring for children.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Microalgae research advances toward goal of net zero carbon emissions
description: Scientists may be on the verge of taking a big step closer to the net-zero carbon emissions goal, thanks to University of Houston research into algae. Hidden potential is being revealed in the major algae studies at the microbial products lab, located at UH at Sugar Land.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Analysis finds diversity on the smallest scales in sulfur-cycling salt marsh microbes
description: At the surface, salt marshes and their windswept grasses can look deceptively simple. But those marshes are teeming with biodiversity, from the insects and migrating birds in the air all the way down to the microbes that live in the soil. Scientists from the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL) have discovered that even among the sulfur-cycling microbes that are responsible for the "rotten egg gas" smell in salt marsh air, diversity extends all the way to genomes and even to individual nucleotides.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How often do you lie? Deception researchers investigate how the recipient and the medium affect telling the truth
description: Prominent cases of purported lying continue to dominate the news cycle. Hunter Biden was charged with lying on a government form while purchasing a handgun. Republican Representative George Santos allegedly lied in many ways, including to donors through a third party in order to misuse the funds raised. The rapper Offset admitted to lying on Instagram about his wife, Cardi B, being unfaithful.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Interacting polarons: Physicists simulate interacting quasiparticles in ultracold quantum gas
description: An electron moving through a solid generates a polarization in its environment due to its electric charge. In his theoretical considerations, the Russian physicist Lev Landau extended the description of such particles by their interaction with the environment and spoke of quasiparticles.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Malaria protein discovery offers path for novel antimalarial intervention strategies
description: The discovery of a malaria protein that helps the parasite grow inside red blood cells and plays a key regulatory role in the parasite's immune evasion tactics could pave the way for new vaccines or therapeutics to combat the deadly infection.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New nanoparticles found to be effective for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis
description: A team of scientists has developed a new solution for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The work has been published in Nature Nanotechnology.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows simple diet swaps can cut carbon emissions and improve your health
description: According to a new study co-authored by a Tulane University researcher and published in the journal Nature Food, making simple substitutions like switching from beef to chicken or drinking plant-based milk instead of cow's milk could reduce the average American's carbon footprint from food by 35%, while also boosting diet quality by between 4–10%, according to the study.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Space is getting crowded with satellites and space junk. How do we avoid collisions?
description: Reports this week suggest a near-collision between an Australian satellite and a suspected Chinese military satellite.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Conducting change: Why copper is key to a renewable future
description: Copper was discovered in the Neolithic Age about 9,000 years ago. It was the first metal used by humans. And we've continued to value copper ever since. The average family home contains more than 90 kilograms of copper. Every time you turn on a light, use a mobile phone or drive a car, you are relying on copper.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New imaging method reveals activity of cells that break down bone
description: Bone may seem as if it's a hard, lifeless structure, but now the cells living within have been imaged in unprecedented detail, thanks to an innovative imaging method developed at the Garvan Institute of Medical Research.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 75% of exclusive hardwood may be illegally harvested
description: The tropical wood type ipê is popular for building exclusive wooden decks, and in North America and Europe, the demand for the material has increased sharply.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Multimodal graphene-based e-textiles for the realization of customized e-textiles developed for the first time
description: A joint research team led by Principal Researcher Soongeun Kwon and Professor Young-Jin Kim has developed graphene-based, customized e-textiles, for the first time in the world. They published their findings in ACS Nano in a paper titled, "Multimodal E-Textile Enabled by One-Step Maskless Patterning of Femtosecond-Laser-Induced Graphene on Nonwoven, Knit, and Woven Textiles."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Variable star RZ Piscium has a compact and highly perturbed debris disk, study finds
description: Using NASA's Spitzer and WISE space telescopes, astronomers from the Steward Observatory and elsewhere have observed a well-known variable star designated RZ Piscium. They found that the star's circumstellar debris disk is compact and highly perturbed. The finding is reported in a paper published October 18 on the pre-print server arXiv.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Beads found in Israel are the oldest known example of the use of organic red pigments
description: A team of archaeologists from The Hebrew University of Jerusalem's Institute of Archaeology, Sorbonne Universite and Conservatoire national des arts et métiers has found the oldest-known example of the use of organic red pigments to color an object—in this case, beads. In their study, reported on the open-access site PLOS ONE, the group used a variety of techniques to identify the source of red coloring on shell beads found in an Israeli cave decades ago.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New model helps researchers get a handle on unpredictable cells
description: In the process of embryonic development, cells take on intricate forms and functions. Patterns emerge from groups of cells, giving the biological tissues form, function, and integrity. It's a complex process that isn't well understood.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Membrane transporter ensures mobility of sperm cells, study finds
description: Special proteins known as membrane transporters are of key importance for the mobility of sperm cells. A research team from the Heidelberg University Biochemistry Center (BZH) headed by Prof. Dr. Cristina Paulino has, with the aid of cryo-electron microscopy, for the first time succeeded in decoding the structure of such a transporter and its mechanism.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Roosters may have passed the self-recognition test
description: A team of neuroscientists and psychologists from the Institute of Agricultural Engineering at the University of Bonn, and the Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience at the University of Bochum, both in Germany, has found possible evidence of roosters passing the self-recognition test. In their paper published in the open-access journal PLOS ONE, the group describes experiments they conducted with roosters and mirrors.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Japanese researchers develop AI-nanopore platform for accurate, rapid COVID-19 testing
description: A rapid, accurate way of testing for COVID-19 infection would be a big step in overcoming the virus' hold over our society. Now, Japanese researchers have developed a promising solution: a novel platform that couples nanopore technology with artificial intelligence. The article, "High-precision rapid testing of omicron SARS-CoV-2 variants in clinical samples using AI-nanopore," was published in Lab on a Chip .
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Deep learning speeds up galactic calculations
description: Supernovae, or exploding stars, play a critical role in the formation and evolution of galaxies. However, key aspects of these phenomena are notoriously difficult to simulate accurately in reasonably short amounts of time.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers advance high-temperature superconductivity in carbon materials
description: In a study published in Advanced Science, researchers led by Prof. Zhong Guohua from the Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology (SIAT) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) have made a prediction regarding superconductivity above 100 K within carbon-cage networks.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Carbon nanotube membrane unleashes the power of permanganate for superior micropollutant removal
description: With the rapid development of industrialization, water pollution is becoming more and more serious. The traditional water treatment method can't effectively remove organic pollutants, so advanced oxidation technology has become a possible solution.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Why do birds flock? Shedding light on collective motions in heterogeneous populations
description: Electrifying plastic beads in a laboratory setup creates flocking behavior similar to that observed in birds. And if you mix beads of two sizes, they will automatically separate. This seemingly simple observation by Alexandre Morin and Samadarshi Maity teaches us about collective motion at all scales. "It's beautiful that something as complex as birds can be understood at its essence through beads."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Molecular scaffold offers new approaches for spinal cord injury
description: Northwestern Medicine scientists have developed a molecular "scaffold" capable of enhancing electrical activity and growth in neurons, which may prove useful in treating spinal cord injuries, according to recent results published in ACS Nano.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nearly 40 years later, one of Colorado's longest-running Superfund sites still has no radioactive waste cleanup plan
description: Jeri Fry was six years old when she toured the uranium mill outside town where her dad worked.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Feds say Colorado River water cuts sufficient enough to stave off immediate risks
description: Current plans for reducing water use along the Colorado River should be sufficient to stave off risks of reservoirs reaching critically low levels over the next three years, according to a new analysis by the federal government.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Stretch of the Central California coast is about to be designated a marine sanctuary. What does that mean?
description: A stretch of land that is expected to be designated as a national marine sanctuary by next year would preserve more than 5,000 square miles of ocean off California's Central Coast.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Can this team create a 'perfect' reef? Why the US military is banking on it
description: The nation's military has been working on a new weapon: Creating a "perfect," self-healing coral reef that can withstand disease, warming temperatures and sea rise.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Atmospheric Waves Experiment launching to space station to study atmospheric waves via airglow
description: NASA's Atmospheric Waves Experiment, or AWE, mission is scheduled to launch to the International Space Station in November 2023, where it will make use of a natural, ethereal glow in Earth's sky to study waves in our planet's atmosphere.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Crusty creatures with 'rather complex' genitalia found in caves: A new species of millipede
description: Deep within a cave in Brazil, a crusty creature crawled along the moist, rocky ground. Something about the subterranean animal caught the attention of nearby scientists.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study suggests cyclones in the Arctic are forming more often and getting stronger
description: A team of Earth scientists from North Carolina State University, the University of Alaska Fairbanks, North Carolina A&T State University, and Sandia National Laboratories has found evidence that suggests cyclones have become more common over the past half-century and have also become stronger.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NY natural history museum changing how it looks after thousands of human remains in collection
description: There are stories in the human bones at the American Museum of Natural History. They tell of lives lived—some mere decades ago, others in past centuries—in cultures around the world.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: China launches new mission to space station
description: China sent a fresh crew to its Tiangong space station on Thursday, in the latest mission for a growing space program that plans to send people to the Moon by 2030.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Arctic archipelago turns the page on its mining past
description: At the old Svea mine in the Arctic, broken railway tracks overgrown with weeds lead nowhere. Of the hundred buildings that once made up the town, there's almost nothing left.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Fire, other ravages jeopardize California's prized forests
description: On a steep mountainside where walls of flames torched the forest on their way toward Lake Tahoe in 2021, blackened trees stand in silhouette against a gray sky.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Turbocharged Otis caught forecasters and Mexico off-guard. Scientists aren't sure why
description: Hurricane Otis turned from mild to monster in record time, and scientists are struggling to figure out how—and why they didn't see it coming.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A research team's 'Robin Hood' approach for tracking biodiversity
description: Elise Zipkin and her team at Michigan State University have developed a sort of "Robin Hood" approach to better understand and protect the world's biodiversity.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
